comments.author: Robertino

comments.text: Hi. I aimed to make them close to s-gauge, but no exact measurements, since I intended to display them on my own printed tracks. Looking forward to the updates!
comments.author: Robertino

comments.text: Hi AgepBiz,
comments.author: agepbiz

comments.text: Can I remix these great models to put on a Trackmaster scale and chassis? (have to ask due to license)
comments.author: chambm

comments.text: Feel free to do so. I have updated the license for this object :)
comments.author: chambm

comments.text: Thanks! I've printed out one at ~85% scale at 0.15 layer height. It's going to be longer than a typical Trackmaster car, so it'll be interesting to see how that works. I just watched the video to see how you did the door handles...are those glued in? I love the detail but I'm skeptical that those would be toddler resistant. :) My bowden setup has some stringiness between the gaps, so it'd probably have been better (for me) to have filled those in and only leave an impression of the edges.
comments.author: agepbiz

comments.text: The doors are printed as one with the body and are not attached on the sides, only the hinges, so filling the gaps will probably work well for you. The filler work great on big open areas, like the roof, not so much on a detailed parts of Annie and Clarabel, so I suggest you ignore Tamiya Putty, It hardens to fast and to much making it very time consuming to work with. I do not have any experience with XTC-3D or similar, so I cannot give you any input on that

Tired of having your cartridges rattle around in your pocket? Small print bed? Other designs don't hold the cartridges in place or have fiddly little pieces?

This single piece holder clips 3x 12g Co2 cartridges into place and allows them to be carried on your belt.

Feedback and suggestions for improvements are welcomed.

Printer:

Maker Select mini V2

Yes

Yes

Fusion 360

Using the dimensions for a 12g cartridge I built a solid form around the shape. The form of the holder is a tight fit so press the cartridge into place and they wont rattle or fall out.

author: koops1983

title: PetraPrinter: Z Axis on mgn12 linear rail t8 leadscrew 2020 frame

description.text:
PetraPrinter: Z-Axis

I spent a few months on design/build my own printer. Meanwhile I learnt the basics of CAD and 3d-printing itself. The design goals were to build a Prusa-style printer with an enclosure to print high-temp materials like ABS. Although today I would not build this machine this way again, there are still some interesting and somewhat unique solutions that worth sharing. Given these reasons, I'm sharing the files component-by-component instead of the full printer, which has some design flaws.

Whatch the video - [youtube link here]
All OpenSCAD files are available on Github
The PetraPrinter Collection on Thingiverse.

About these parts

The three parts are a bottom motor holder, a top 608 bearing holder and the mgn12h-mounted carriage itself using 4x M3x15. The X axis is joined with the Z carriage using two M5x10 cap-headed screws. The carriage houses an ant-backlash T8 nut (see pictures for details).

Note: You can print all parts without support, but the inner part of the carriage will look ugly. As that part has no mechanical function, just go for it.

description.text: This remix of Matt Moses' public domain Wankel engine model simply adds a crank handle part, allowing the motor to be turned more easily. The eccentric part is also modified with a notch to fit the handle. You can use the other parts directly from the original. More details on this build: http://www.thingiverse.com/make:65562 http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oEjMcKEQi7A

title: Anet A8 Filament Guide / Dry Box Tube Attachment

description.text:
Because of humidity problems with a PET-G filament spool, i built a dry box for my filament rolls with feeder and teflon tube. I designed this attachment point for my printer, so that it is high and centered above the extruder. The frame replaces the standoffs between the frame and display.

FreeCAD file available on request.

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

20%

======== FR =========
Un petit outil simple et rapide à imprimer pour monter ou démonter les ampoules GU10 quand nos doigts ne passent pas.
Peut être imprimé en 15 min avec du PLA bas de gamme.
J'ai passé 3 heures et imprimé plusieurs pièces test avant de trouver le bon compromis qui se clipse bien alors merci pour ton "like" et "follow", ça fait toujours plaisir ;-)

EDIT 21/08/2017 : Je viens d'ajouter un deuxième STL "concept2" : plus grand et plus ergonomique.

======== EN =========
A simple tool to help you to mount and unmount GU10 bulb when your fingers can't.
You can print it in 15min with the cheapest PLA.
It took me 3 hours and makes diférents version to find the good "cliping" solution so, don't forget to like and follow ;-)

EDIT 21/08/2017 : add a new STL "concept2" : bigger for better ergonomy

description.text:
The universal and quick dowelling tool for corner and T-butt connections. For 6mm wood dowels and 18mm panel.

You will also need ball bearing 626ZZ http://www.zkl-loziska.cz/Vyrobky-info/INA/-zla-kategorie-/Lozisko-626-ZZ/ and steal thorn 6mm x cca 15mm.

Usages: like in the pictures.

Printed: PLA, Infill 70%, 0.5mm

This is one of two Cold War era Federal Thunderbolt 1000 Air Raid Sirens that I'm going to upload. I found the files who knows where, and have converted them to STL's. The files are pretty OK really, but I've left them alone for the most part so that they can be sliced and modified however you want them. These sirens were made by Federal from about the mid 50s until the 80s with only minor changes, and are a unit of YOUR CIVIL DEFENSE!

I noticed when printing ABS the heated bed has a large effect on the accuracy of the Pinda probe and it changes your z height, when cooling this manually by blowing on it, it fixed the problem, so I quickly threw this Pinda cooler together which screws directly onto the original mounting point for the Prusa I3 MK2S standard print cooler.

Personally, I print ABS without cooling the print so cooling the pinda probe using this attachment at the start of a print worked wonders for me, I get perfectly accurate Z height with this attachment.

When using this probe I use Octoprint, which enables me to activate my fan before I press print, if you do not do this then you will need to edit your G-code before you print and ensure the print fan turns on before you home and calibrate z height.

Edit:
The Gcode you need is "M106 S255" to turn the fan on and "M106 S0" to turn the fan off.

In Slic3r there is a section called print settings and under custom Gcode you would put "M106 S255" before G28 (home) and "M106 S0" after the G80 code (mesh bed leveling).

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

ABS
Support to bed only (0.1mm from part)
Bed: 100°C
Hot end: 255°C

comments.text: Nice job on this. I finally got around to trying it out after getting frustrated with the constant fiddling I've been doing while printing in my enclosure. I print mostly PETG on my Prusa i3 mk2. Prior to using this my z height would be off every time I went to print, because of the temperature drift when printing inside an enclosure. The first time I printed would usually be OK, but if I went to do subsequent prints I would have to either change the z-height or wait for the printer to completely cool down before printing again. Not ideal for my situation, because when I want to print, I usually am printing for an afternoon back to back.

comments.author: mrojod

comments.text: Just a thought- would there be enough air flow to do both part cooling and pinda cooling if you put a few holes along the bottom of the cooler? It may not be a perfect solution, but I think it could work. Reason being: you don't need to run the fan for the PINDA after leveling the bed, so ABS would still be fine (since you don't want a part cooling fan). For PETG, you would just leave the fan on and it would cool both the PINDA as well as the part.  The part cooling still probably wouldn't be as good as the stock cooler, but it might be good enough...

This is the other cold war era Federal Thunderbolt 1000 Air Raid Siren that I have. All I've done is convert it to an STL file for printing, it has otherwise been left alone for you to modify however you want. I can't recall where the original file was sourced, because I get them from everywhere. This is a unit of YOUR CIVIL DEFENSE! Federal produced these largely unchanged from the mid 50s or so until the 80s. During the cold war these loud buggers were everywhere, and at a moments notice would warn you of an impending attack from those pesky reds or even a tornado, but mostly (Thankfully!) they just sounded off at noon on Wednesday for the weekly test.

comments.text: I design and Print working sirens. I have done a couple but have not posted them. I want to but I have to make all the files presentable. print_settings.Notes:: I made the reticle stand out more by pausing the print and swapping to black filament for that portion, then pausing again to swap back for the arches. It would work fine printed all one color, but a light color is best to make the shadow stand out and keep it from heating up in he sun too much.

description.text:
Solar panels work best when pointed directly at the sun, but the exact angle can be difficult to eyeball. This device, attached to a panel with 2-sided tape, takes out the guesswork.

When the panel is off-angle, as in the second picture, the shadow of the arches will be off-center of the reticle on the base. When the shadow is brought in line with the reticle, as in the third picture, it means that the panel is perfectly orthogonal to the light source.

I made the reticle stand out more by pausing the print and swapping to black filament for that portion, then pausing again to swap back for the arches. It would work fine printed all one color, but a light color is best to make the shadow stand out and keep it from heating up in he sun too much.

When I happened upon this file, I was stoked! I've wanted an original ACL sign forever, but they are few and far between. The way I did it though, is that I scaled it way up, 10" diameter, and I didn't slice it or anything. I let it print with the perceived problems my 3d program said that the file had. The only thing I had to do at that scale was smooth out the edges of the sign to make it totally round. Also, I just did it all in white, and I will hand paint the lettering. I hope this helps!

title: Replacement Latch for Lokk Latch Deluxe

description.text: Created this to replace a broken latch on my gate. The gate latch is D&D Technologies Lokk Latch Deluxe. Here is a link: http://ddtechglobal.com/product/lokklatch_deluxe. Just need a short piece of aluminum rod. If your latch has broke it is probably due too much force being exerted on the latch. To fix this bolt a piece of angle iron to the fence post with some padding glued to one side. Bolt it to the post that the catch is located on so that it will help absorb the impact of the gate slamming shut. I bolted mine near the top of the post so that it catches the gate just before the latch gets hit by the catch. This has fixed the issue completely.

description.text:
Here are golf balls with different numbers of dimples. They are each provided in solid (need supports to print) and split-joinable versions. For the joinable versions, you may want to edit the tolerances in the scad file. My printer has pretty poor tolerances, so on yours the fit might be loose.

I haven't actually printed it yet. I expect that even the split versions will have trouble with the lower dimples, so you might want to add supports and clean up, or just not worry about a few damaged dimples.

The golf balls are generated using my approximate Tammes problem solver (for more information on the solver, see here). On Windows, you can download tammes.exe and then run from the commandline:

tammes -scad 336 > 336.scad

to generate an OpenSCAD file with 336 dimples. On other operating systems, just compile tammes.c. The calculations are probably too computationally intensive for the OpenSCAD file to do them.

See this video for the Tammes solver at work.

title: Super Nintendo (SNES) PAL Raspberry Pi 3 Case

description.text:
Still a work in progress!

I was tired of waiting for the SNES Mini so I decided to make my own! This is a case for the Raspberry Pi 3.

It also features a fully functioning controller port for a SNES controller! The case is designed for this port: http://www.ebay.com/itm/SNES-Controller-female-connector-Socket-Vertical-Mount/152485369594?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649

If there is enough intereset I can write a guide how to hook up the port to the RPi.

This design also features a PowerBlock from petrockblock and can be found here: https://blog.petrockblock.com/powerblock/
It is used for the soft power switch as well as the LED. Very handy!

UPDATE 13.09.17:

New files has been uploaded. There is now a lip on the top for the cover to fit in nicely. There is also a mount for a small slide switch for turning on the pi. I also added some pictures to show how everything should go together!

For the slide switch I used something like this:

https://www.digikey.de/product-detail/de/e-switch/EG1201/EG1901-ND/101720

For the microswitch you need one with a height of 9.5mm like the ones here:
http://katalog.we-online.de/en/em/TATV_6X6_THT_4301x6xxx7x6

Here is a quick schematic on how to hook up the controller port to the Pi. Connect them according to the diagram. I didn't draw the 5V and GND line, but you need to connect them to a 5V and GND pin on the Raspberry Pi!
After you connected the pins according to the diagram you need to install the gamecon_gpio_rpi driver through the Retropie package installer.
Then you need to add the following line to your /opt/retropie/configs/all/autostart.sh:

sudo modprobe gamecon_gpio_rpi map=0,0,0,1,0,0

After that you need to configure the SNES controller like any other controller in Retropie!

09.10.2017:
Planning to do a major revamp on the design. Stay tuned!

03.11.2017:
Finally uploaded the updated files! The following things have changed:

  • Fully working cartridge slot! The cartridge cover is not for show anymore. Also the cartridge eject button is working. For this to work I had to make the case 4mm taller and move the RPi3 down. Still working on a NFC circuit that will read the carts, as I put NFC tags inside them.
  • Redesigned the power button. Now it is way easier to assemble and print.
  • Found more or less the best matching SNES colors. If you are in Germany you can buy the following filaments
    -- Main Body & Cartridges: http://3dk.berlin/de/pla/92-pla-filament-platingrau.html
    -- Cover: http://shop.3d-filament.de/de/3d-druck-filament-1-75mm/pla/oem/175-pla-grau.html
    -- Switches and Cartridge Cover: http://3dk.berlin/de/pla/74-pla-filament-dunkelgrau.html

TODO list:

  • Add stl files for the cartridge. I didn't design the cartridge, I only modified them. I have to talk to the creator to get the permission to upload the files here.
    Done! Added the files!
  • Add a version of the case to use without the PowerBlock. You will of course lose the power button functionality.
    Done! Added the files!
  • Try to make a front cover for the second type of SNES controller port that floats around on ebay. It has a much bigger rim so I'm not sure if I'm able to do that without modifying the port itself. Probably the top and bottom rim has to be removed.
    You need to modify this type of controller port. It will fit inside the faceplate afterwards! Will try to incorporate that into the manual as well.
  • Add a multi-material version
  • Make a detailed step-by-step instruction. Especially the cartridge mechanics need some explanation. I will print the whole case again and make pictures for every step while assembling it. Almost done! You can find parts of it on the bottom of the page!
  • NFC circuitry with custom made emulationstation software. I'm already working on my custom build of emulationstation that is able to read and write the NFC tags.
    Done! Hardware and software are working! I can now read the tags inside the cartridges to start the game and also write to them trough EmulationStation. Putting the NFC reader into the housing is very hard though. I will try to add that to the manual as well! Sourcecode can be found here: https://retropie.org.uk/forum/topic/14390/nfc-enabled-emulationstation

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.05 - 0.2

Infill:

20

Notes:

I oriented the stl files like they should be printed! No need to rotate them.

SNES_Pi_Bottom: Supports
SNES_Pi_Top: Supports
SNES_PI_Cover: Supports
SNES_PI_Cartridge_Switch_Lever: Supports
SNES_PI_Cartridge_Insert: Supports
SNES_PI_Cart_Front and SNES_PI_Cart_Back: I suggest a brim of about 2 - 3mm to ensure the cartridge doesn't fall over. The cartridge is orientated that way because it will give a much smoother finishes than laying it flat on its back.

This design is based on the design of Vitting. Thanks Vitting for letting me upload this design!

His design can be found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/Vitting/designs

The cartridge design is based on daftmikes cartridge which can be found here: https://www.myminifactory.com/object/mini-snes-cartridges-46438

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/7j7E77MLkHk" ></iframe>
NFC in action!

0. Stuff you need


(Not everything is included in the picture)

  • 3D printed parts

    • Multiple version
      • Either print the PowerBlock or the No PowerBlock version
      • If you don't want the SNES controller port you need to print the according faceplate
    • Optional parts
      • NFC antenna block, only if you want the NFC functionalit

  • Mechanics

    • 3mm rod
      • 1x 67mm
      • 1x 42mm
    • Switches
      • Pushbutton 9.5mm high
      • Small slide switch: Link
    • SNES controller port
      • There are two version for the port.
        • Black one like this: Link. This one will fit with no modifications.
        • Gray one like you see in my picture. This one has to be modified to fit.
    • Springs
      • 7mm x 12.5mm spring
      • Spring wire or SS316L 24ga vaping wire
    • Screws
      • 2x M3 x 6mm
      • 2x M3 x 20mm
      • 3,2mm washers
      • M3 nuts
      • C 2,2mm x 13mm countersunk
    • Zipties
    • Piece of self-adhesive felt

  • Electronics

    • 3mm red LED
    • Raspberry Pi 3
    • Heatsinks
    • 25mm 5V Fan
    • PowerBlock (optional)
    • NFC reader (optional): Link
    • NFC tag sticker (optional): Link
    • Wire in differents colors
  • Tools
    • Screwdriver with different bits
    • Scissors
    • Box cutter
    • Glue for plastics
    • Hotglue gun
    • Sanding paper
    • Electric drill
    • Drilling bits
    • Soldering iron
    • Solder
1. Assembly Cover

  • Cover
  • Reset Switch Inlay
  • Power Switch Inlay
  • Power Switch
  • Glue for plastics

Grab your glue and put a little bit on the ridges of the reset switch portion of the cover. Then put the reset switch inlay on the cover and press it down.

Put the power switch into the cover and make sure it has room to move up and down. The ridges of the reset switch have to move into the holes in the cover. You can testfit the inlay over the switch to make sure it moves all the way. After that put glue on the left and right ridges on the cover and inser the inlay. Make sure not to accidentally put glue on the switch!

Your finished product should look like this!

  • Cartridge Insert
  • Cartridge Block 1
  • Cartridge Block 2
  • 3mm rod
  • Drill
  • Drill bits 3mm & 4.5mm
  • Spring wire (I used SS316L 24ga vaping wire)

You need to cut a 3mm rod to about 66mm. The one I got in the picture was just a little bit too long. 66mm should be fine!

Take your drill and a 3mm drill bit and make sure the hole in the cartridge insert is 3mm. The rod has to move and rotate smoothly through the hole.

Test fit the cartridge insert and the rod by putten the insert into the cover and pushing the rod through the hole in the cover. If the rod doesn't go in easily you might to have to drill that hole as well.

Take the two blocks and your glue. Put the glue in the designated spaces on the cover. Block 1 (the one with the ledge goes on the top (behind the cartridge insert). The ledge has to be on the top and has to be orientated to the cartridge insert. You can see the orientation in the next picture! Block 2 goes on the other spot. Orientation doesn't matter here, but make sure you put the block as far away from the cartridge slot as possible, but still inside the designated area. Otherwise the antenna might not fit.

It should look like this!

Now comes the fun part. Take your wire, your drill and 4.5mm drill bit and put them into the drill like I did in the picture. Make sure the wire is firm inside the chuck.

Hold the wires (I suggest with some pliers) and start rotating the drill. After about 10-12 rounds you can stop.

Cut the wire so that the coil looks exactly like in the picture! One side of the wire has to be longer than the other and the shorter side has to be bent into the middle of the coil.

Remove the cartridge insert from the cover and testfit the spring. It should look like this! Be sure that the long end doesn't point downwards! Otherwise you won't get enough spring tension.

Now fit everything on the cover. You need to have the spring on the cartridge insert and then push the rod through the holes and spring. It's a little bit tricky. You also need to make sure that the long end is pushing against Block 1 like in the picture above.

  • Reset Switch
  • Reset Switch Insert

Put the reset switch into the cover. Make sure the orientation is correct! The switch is slanted, you can check the corrent orientation by flipping the cover and looking at the switch from the top. Put glue on the two ridges and make sure not to get any glue onto the switch. Push the insert into the designated areas.

Should look like this!

  • Small Slide Switch
  • Pushbutton 9.5mm high
  • Hot glue gun

Put the pushbotton into the hole of the reset switch insert. Make sure everything fits and then put some hot glue around the switch.

Push the power switch all the way to the top (like in the picture). Take the slide switch and make sure the switch is also all the way to the top. Put a very small dab of hot glue on the switch and push it into the power switch hole. Always make sure the switch is still up! Afterwards put hot glue around the switch. If the switch is not completely inside the designated area: Don't worry! That is normal.

Congratulations! You assembled the cover!

2. Assembly Top

  • Previously assembled cover
  • Top
  • Drill with 3mm drill bit
  • Red LED

Push the cover into the top. It should fit quite snugly. Turn in around and put glue in all the areas I marked red in the picture. Make sure your cartridge slot works! If there is any problem you have to fix it NOW. You won't be able to remove the mechanics after this step!

Should look like this!

Take your drill with a 3mm drill bit and enlarge the hole in the top for the LED. DO NOT drill all the way through. Just enough for the LED to fit. You don't need to go deep for that AT ALL!

Put the red LED in there, bend the leads 90° and put hot glue on there to secure the LED.

3. Assembly Front

  • Front
  • SNES Controller Port (doesn't matter which of the two)
  • If you don't want the SNES Controller Port you need the Front NoConnector! You also don't need the steps here and can jump the next step!

If you have the grey SNES controller port you need to remove the rim from the top and bottom of the port! Check the picture to see how much you have to remove. You can use a sharp knife to remove the plastic quite easily.

It should fit into the front quite well if you removed enough plastic! Be sure not to overdo it, otherwise you will have gaps!

If you have the black connector you don't need to do any modifications.

Grab the front and some glue. Put glue on the ridges.

Put the connector inside and put some more glue on top to make sure the connector stays where it is supposed to.

Done!

4. Assembly Bottom
  • Bottom
  • Raspberry Pi 3
  • Heatsinks
  • PowerBlock (optional)
  • PowerBlock Distancer (optional)
  • M3 x 6mm screws
  • M3 x 20mm screws
  • M3 nuts
  • 3,2mm washers
  • Soldering iron
  • Solder
  • Drill
  • 2mm drill bit

Take your drill and a 2mm drill bit and widen the holes in the Bottom for the screws to fit more easily. By the way, you don't need the two holes in the front. I didn't use them because the screws look ugly on the front as they are seen quite easily.

Here you can see the bigger holes.

Take a sharp knife and remove the excess plastic from the top. Otherwise there will be a gap when you screw the Top on the Bottom.

The the same steps on the Top as well. But don't drill all the way through of course!

Take the Raspberry Pi 3 and put the heatsinks on there!

Get your PowerBlock and remove the pin headers from the LED and Switch terminals. They have to go unfortunately, otherwise the cartridges won't fit! Put some fresh solder on the bottom and heat it put until you can pull it out with some pliers. Be careful not to damage anything!

Take a M3 x 6mm screw and screw it into the four hole to pretap the holes. It makes it easier to fit the screws later (Ignore the lever mechanism in the picture).

Get some M3 x 20mm screws, an M3 nut, the PowerBlock Distancer and washers. Pun them together like in the picture. I only put one washer at the very bottom. Two or three would be better! You also may need to drill the hole of the PowerBlock with a 3,2mm drill bit if the screw doesn't fit. Of course do the same for the other screw as well!

Put the Raspberry Pi 3 and the PowerBlock into the case now. Use M3 x 6mm for the holes without the PowerBlock! As before: Ignore the lever. I messed up the order while doing the pictures. If you put in the lever mechanism after putting in the Pi your life will be a lot easier! I also forgot to remove the pin headers from the PowerBlock in this picture...

  • Cartridge Switch Base
  • Cartridge Switch Lever
  • 3mm rod
  • 7mm x 12.5mm spring

It is now time to assemble the lever mechanism. You need a 3mm again, but now the length should be 42-43mm.

Assemble everything like in the picture. Try not to drill the holes larger for the rod to fit. The rod should be inside quite firmly. That way it won't slide out again.

Put glue on the designated are on the Bottom and put the assembled lever on there!

It should look like this...actually it should look more like the picture above, as you already should have the Raspberry Pi in your case.

That was the bottom!

5. Assembly Top, Bottom & Front

  • Assembled Front
  • Assembled Bottom
  • Assembled Top
  • Cartridge Switch
  • LED Insert
  • Piece of self-adhesive felt

Take a sharp knife and cut away the plastic on the Top until the Front, Top and Bottom fit nicely. During printing the Top has to be printed with supports. That screws up the precise height of that part so some aftercare is needed. Be sure not to remove too much.

After you are sure that everything is going to fit put some glue on the Bottom like in the picture and press the Front into it. Align the Front and put the Top on it. I suggest you screw the Top to the Bottom now until the glue is dried up.

It should look like this!

While it is drying take the LED insert and cut off the triangle part at the bottom (I really need to design that part again...maybe later). Take a sharp knife or some sanding paper and sand the sides down until it fits into the hole for the LED.

Like this!

Take a piece of felt and cut a part out of it in the shape of the cartridge switch. Put the piece of felt under the switch. After the glue on the Front dried you can unscrew the Top again and put the cartridge switch inside the case.

Now you are finished...for now!

You can put cartridges into the case right now, but they won't be properly aligned as there is still a gap in the front where the NFC antenna is supposed to be. I will also show how to hook up everything for the electronics!

But that's it for now!

description.text:
UPDATED VERSION

I designed this case to hold my spare nozzles for my Prusa i3. The case is printed in one piece with functional hinge and clip to keep the case closed when not in use. Never mislay those nozzles again. This one has text 'Nozzles 0.4mm' let me know if you would prefer one that just says 'Nozzles' or blank and i will add additional versions.

This version uses less supports as the top is printed directly off the build plate so only support required is for the hinge.

STL 'Nozzle_Case_Nozzles_Text.stl' = Top With text reading 'Nozzles'
STL 'Nozzle_Case_0.4Text.stl' = Top With text reading 'Nozzles 0.4mm'
STL 'Nozzle_Case_Blank_Top.stl' = Blank Top

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

There will be a tiny bit of support that prints in the clip between the top and little notch which is used on the clip into the bottom half of the case which if you forget to remove could potentially cause the clip to snap, but as i've always removed that i've not had that happen to me personally.

comments.text: Thanks for sharing! I'm also a happy MK2S owner! Just picked up some nozzles and will be needing this!
comments.author: Sarek27

comments.text: No special sli3cr settings. Was running stock profile and speeds. I do have custom firmware installed on my mk2s to increase the number of bed correction points to get a more even first layer across the bed. Auto levelling can only do so much. I used this thread on the prusa forum to implement the custom firmware. https://shop.prusa3d.com/forum/prusa-i3-kit-building-calibrating-first-print-main-f6/hyperfine-bed-leveling--t4330.html

This is simply a block to stabilise the frame .... meh

Another of the many files I have scoured from the vast wasteland that is the internet. This is a classic and beautiful 1936 BSA Empire Star Motorcycle. Kudos to whomever drew this 3D model up. It most certainly wasn't me! I can build you a real one from a rusty pile of parts, and restore it to perfection, but I have yet to figure out how to draw something like this up in a cad program. I'm learning though...All I did to this file was convert it to STL format, and repair and clean it up to the best of my abilities so that I could print it out and add it to my collection. I really, really hope that one of you gurus will remix this bad boy and chop it into about 100 detailed pieces! It would make for one GREAT model! I have about 50 more vintage bike files that I am working through converting and repairing and I plan on publishing all of them...

Read some things about this fantastic motor bike here :

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BSA_Empire_Star

comments.text: I tried to limit current as a solution to the heat problem but it gets to stall point first. Since my extruder parts are 3d printed it can cause them to warp slightly and make the gears mesh less precisely. So far adding an aluminum heat sink has helped a lot but this is the final solution if need be. Thank you so much, this design seems superior to the others I have considered
comments.author: mcmasterp

comments.text: why would you need to cool the extruder motor? its the motor with the least amount of power dissipation
comments.author: whostech

comments.text: if your stepper gets really hot then most probably the current is too high. You would need to regulate the current to the one specified for the motor using those little potentiometers (trimmers) on the motor control boards.

title: Leadfoot (Pb') case for Raspberry Pi Zero W

description.text:
A Leadfoot case has "ballast" (sand) in the base to make it a little heavier. Sits better on the desk when you connect cables etc.

The case in the picture, I printed in PETG. Fits Raspberry Pi Zero W. The classic Zero should work as well (though there is a hole for the camera connector).

There's a hole in the sidewall where the sand goes. Then use the plug or just fill the hole with glue.

author: stellarinnovation

title: Micromake C1 Y-Axis linear guide mod with belt tensioner

description.text:
This is a mod to replace the wheels carriage of the Y-axis of a Micromake C1 with a MGN linear guide. These guides can be bought cheaply on eBay or Aliexpress. The mod improves the stability of the bed and, at least in my case, improves the quality of the print. It also includes a tensionner mechanism for the belt.

The mod has been designed to fit in the standard acrylic parts delivered with the original Micromake kit. I know that some parts included in the delivered kits have evolved with the time (some parts in my kit look a little different than the one shown in the official assembly videos). So if my mod doesn't fit perfectly on your machine, don't hesitate to contact me, I may be able to generate a variant for you. I have no idea if the mod will fit on a metal parts version of the printer.

Parts are foreseen to be printed with the orientation as they appears on the Thingiviews. No support needed.

The included PDF is a 3D PDF, so you can move the assembly view if you want to better see how it is constructed.

I have also machined a new version of the bed support plate for my machine (8mm black MDF). This is not mandatory to be able to use my mod. You can reuse the standard plate delivered with your kit and drill in it the holes for the MGN carriage.

The following parts are needed:

  • For the rear holder
    1x Printed rear holder
    2x F623ZZ bearings
    1x M3x20 screw
    1x M3 nut
    2x M3 washers (standard DIN125 washer, i.e dia 7mm, thickness 0.5mm)
    Two original M3 screws of the kit are reused to fix the assembly to the acrylic and to the stepper motor.

  • For the front slider
    Tensioner Screw:
    1x Printed knob
    1x M4x25 screw
    2x M4 nuts
    1x M4 washer
    Moving roller assembly:
    1x Printed front slider
    2x F623ZZ bearings
    1x M3x18 screw
    1x M3 nut
    6x M3 washers
    I know that it can be difficult to find a M3x18 screw in most hobby shops. But in order to be able to reuse the standard acrylic parts delivered with the kit, I have been obliged to use that exact size. You will find plenty of that size on Aliexpress, but you can also cut a longer screw to size, this is easy to do. The screw must be with a thin head, so button or cheese head. A screw with a socket head (DIN912) will probably not fit. I had also a design of the slider that used a M3x16 screw, but it had very fine walls and I thought it will not be strong enough.
    Look on the picture to see how the 6 washers are used. There are 2 groups of 2 washers on each extremity. These slide in a slot of the front holder and help to guide the moving part. Note that the parts of the moving roller assembly need to be assembled with the slider already inserted in the holder and after that the tensionner screw has been screwed to the slider.

  • For the front holder fixed roller assembly
    1x Printed front holder
    2x F623ZZ bearings
    1x M3x20 screw
    1x M3 nut
    2x M3 washers
    The complete front holder assembly is fixed to the original acrylic parts using the original M6 screw of the kit.

  • For the linear guide
    1x MGN15H carriage with 300mm rail
    2x M3x10 screws and T-nuts (at least 2, for fixing the rail to the profile)
    4x M3xXX screws
    1x M3x30 screw
    1x M3 nut
    Using a 300mm rail allows to keep the 245mm range of the original printer. There is room on the profile to use a longer rail if you want to increase the usable range (you may need a larger bed too).
    The 4 M3xXX screws are to fix the bed holder to the MGN carriage. XX is your bed holder thickness + 4mm, i.e. 12mm in my case.
    The M3x30 is used to trigger the limit switch (look at the picture).

  • For each hardstop block (not mandatory, but will prevent derailing if the firmware tries to move the bed to far)
    1x Printed hardstop block
    1x M3x10 screw
    1x M3 T-nut

  • If you want to use the same belt clamps that I'm using, for each clamp
    1x Printed belt clamp
    2x M4 screws (size depending of your bed holder thickness)
    2x M4 nuts
    The belt clamps need to be printed with 0.1mm resolution. If you are using Simplify3d you can print the first 2.6mm with 0.2mm resolution and then switch to 0.1mm resolution for the remaining layers using a second print profile.

Printer:

Micromake C1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm (0.1mm for the belt clamps)

Infill:

80%

description.text:
Remix of a great design of gringer. More suitable for smaller kids - longer mouth part (in original design kids often cover by mouth also the sound producing opening), narrower air stream (the whistle can produce also softer sound).
Added one more teeth-holder and two lines of customizable text. When printed for small kids as an emergency-whistle, I usually use the first line for the name of the kid and the second line for the emergency phone number. When printed for adults, I am using the first line (name or nickname or so) only.
The air bubbles in infill are big enough to allow the whistle be floating on the water.

comments.text: I've printed a few of these now and I've consistently had trouble with the top thread of the body needing some cleanup before the lid will screw on. How did you make the model? Any chance you could post the original file so I could maybe take a stab at cleaning it up?
comments.author: johnboiles

comments.text: I guess you are having a clearance issue? try change your slicer setting to compensate for that, that is called horizontal expansion in Cura, try set it to -0.2 or so
comments.author: johnboiles

comments.text: I think the issue is that the spacing on the top-most thread on the bottom piece gets smaller and smaller as it reaches the end of the model. Watch the thread spacing on the top thread as you rotate the model horizontally. If I cut away the top thread it fits fine. See this gif and watch the spacing in the top thread get smaller and smaller.
comments.author: alexacw

comments.text: Wow, i see, i must have reversed some steps, i will fix it when i have time, thanks for letting me know this fault

Made this to join 2 or more Walmart Mainstays Parson tables together similar to the IKEA Lack table enclosures everyone is using. Made this as minimal as possible while still keeping it extremely rigid and strong.

  • The risers must be installed prior to screwing the legs on.
  • 68mm riser built in to allow an Anet A8 to sit nicely between 2 of the tables with a little height room to spare.
  • I designed this to use 10mm screws, but should fit others also.
  • You can fit 4 on a 220mm X 220mm bed together to print all needed at the same time.

Another of my giant collection of files which I am going through and making printable. I can't stress enough that I didn't do the design work, I merely converted this to STL format, and did a quick clean-up and repair. Whomever drew this up did an excellent job! This time its a classic beauty in the form of a 1969 Moto Guzzi V7 Special. I'm going to carefully print this and add it to my scale and 1:1 vehicle collection, and now YOU can too! I repaired what I could. The only thing it could really use is accurately sculpted emblems. The detail was lost, and I don't know how to fix it yet. This one deserves to be sliced into 100 pieces, remixed and super detailed by one of you wizards out there! It's plenty cool as-is though...

Read some things about this beautiful classic road bike here :

https://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moto_Guzzi_V7_Special

I created inverted pedals since for the fanatec csr pedals since I didn't want to buy the brackets sold by fanatec. The brackets feel very solid and hug the sort of humps on the pedal base, and holes line up perfectly for the bolts. The only problem with the design is that I miscalculated the opening where part of the pedal assembly will slide into by 4mm on the brake pedal bracket, and about 2 mm on the gas pedal. if you want to file it down a little it can slide in for an even more secure fit, but works just as well if you leave it as is. This is more of a prototype because of this and may update this in the future if I get enough requests to do so. For infill id recommend 70-100 if you like smashing your foot down clutch kicking and what not for most rigidity and filament saving if you need so. Id also recommend a 15mm brim with a .3mm initial layer height if you run into warping/prints coming off bed for bigger prints such as this. Enjoy!

author: lacurie

description.text:
This is the best and most easy way to level the Hotbed for Printing...

See the hole Process @ https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GPd0UuvIyA8&feature=youtu.be

It will print a grid of 2 perimeter lines on the Bed.
If you lower the Printing speed for first layer to 30-45mm/s you can easily level your Bed while printing the Grid...

The Grid is 280x280mm so u can use an pre-oultline with max 10mm distance to the print Object.

Be carefull with your Glass Clips!

print_settings.Notes:: Pretty standard settings.  If you make it bigger, keep the hole size 5mm.  NASA says that's the size the hole needs to be

description.text:
Being based in Canada has its advantages. Unfortunately, one of those is not Nasa producing things specific to your province or country. Failing to find a nice, flat, model of Ontario or Canada, I made this eclipse viewer out of the old Toronto Maple Leafs sign. Designed to print on the MP select mini, it will fit on a 120 x 120 mm build plate.

Instructions: Just keep your back to the sun, hold the plate ~1-1.5 m off the ground, and you will see the sun projected onto the ground through the 5mm hole. Try taking a picture including the plate, your shadow, and the view of the sun reflected on the ground. I know I will! Will be uploading a picture of it in action after tomorrow. Sorry if it's a bit late!

https://eclipse2017.nasa.gov/2d3d-printable-pinhole-projectors

title: Anet A8 - X Axis Belt Tensioner Idler

description.text:
My take on an X Axis Belt Tensioner for the Anet A8

2 versions: 8,75mm Inner Gap and 10,00mm Inner Gap

Updated to have the nut on the correct side. Sorry for this mistake. If you printed the old design, glue the nuts in place. Glue the nuts in the new design also for better performance.

Notice that it's not symmetric, the side with the nut goes towards the back of your printer.

IMPORTANT: To install this version you DO NEED some extra belt length, so if you cut it just enough when you built your A8 this version wont work for you. Try instead something like this thing

You will need some of the extra M3 Bolts and Nuts and a pair or washers (Optional) but I think even when they are tricky to install, it's nice to have them between the bearing and the sides of the idler.

PS: It should work without any problem with this other modification

Hope you like it, and as always, photos are welcome if you make it. Feedback is also very welcome.

This is a customizable paper clip that allows you to modify the size as well as add text.  
The SCAD file was generated from scratch after examining several others.  
If you push the limits some of the parameters, you will find that it is not yet perfect, but it seems good enough to publish and hopefully, it will be of some benefit to others.  
If you are using a single-extruder, select "both clip and text".  
If you are using a dual-extruder, you can select "clip only" to generate the STL for the clip, and then "text only" to generate the STL for the text.  
I have found these to be great gifts for friends and colleagues, and they also work well as paper clips.  
Note: I am seeing somewhat different results with the Customizer than I was using OpenSCAD. Specifically, the Customizer is having a much more difficult time automatically determining the length of the clip.   
Please be patient and I'll see if I can fix it.

comments.text:
It's a great design.
Don't forget to drill the holes into the small connectors like I did, otherwise it will simply not work.
I printed with a low shell and infill at the beginning, so the water was dripping through. After raising the shell to 0.9 and 50% or more infill it worked.
Apply some hose tensioner after you put the hose on so it won't drip out or come away if you put more pressure on the water. Thank you to Dbach_MetalWorks for this!
p.s. I'm printing in PLA so some small connectors still breakes easily, I bet ABS works just great.

author: raif7

description.text:
This is a replacement for the backside edge protectors/case feet of older (and possibly newer, not sure) Hewlett Packard measurement devices. The design closely follows the originals and should therefore fit well. I originally made these for my 8565A spectrum analyzer, but they are used in many different devices and as far as I know Agilent/Keysight still uses the same case designs.

Print these standing up with the smallest surface down on the bed. The outward slopes will print just fine without support, so the software should not generate any. However, the inside of the two screw holes must be supported from the build plate up. You won't need to enable brims if the surface is clean, however.

I used PLA, but PETG might be a good choice to increase durability.
Note that the holes for screws are tight! This is intended, and is likewise in the original part. Also, the tight fit of the rectangular intendations to the case backside is intended.

This is compatible only with the Standard V3. The ARES/S&T version with the micro-switch one doesn't work. Those use a different selector tor plate.

A simple tool helping to get the Ultimaker sliding blocks well aligned.
Nothing revolutionary here, but this method help me to get a better tuning of the machine.

1 - Clip two of them(one at each side of the head) on the same axis (Y OR X)
2 - Check using the frame edge if both tools reach the frame edge, if not, your sliding blocks need some adjustment.
3 - In that case, loosen the pulleys on the side you want to adjust the sliding block position, then move backward or forward the block until the axis tool on the misaligned side, finally reach the frame edge. Note : Depending on where the screws on your pulleys are placed, you might not be able to reach them to loosen the pulleys. If so, try the opposite frame edge by rotating both tools on the axis and check if the pulleys screws are reachable. You may also reduce the length of the tools to fit your needs or even put a reference mark on both axis tools, once you managed to have the pulleys screws accessible. Edit : I have uploaded the SKP file so you can easily change it in sketchup ! (I know that this tool could be shorter !)

title: The Great Gratouille ! The nozzle cleaner

description.text:
Dear friends,
I'm proud to present to you the best tool for 3d printing. An example of the french genius in it's most advanced form. After the bike, the Braille alphabet, the photography, the computer and the bra, here is... the Great Gratouille!
Did you never cried in looking your filament which continues to emerge of the nozzle during the heating? Or after an extruder calibration? Or after a filament changing? Or juste before the printing, making a big ball that will destroy your first layer, giving you cold sweats?
Forget all that. It is an old souvenir.
Now with the Great Gratouille, you'll always be ready to clean the nozzle, until the last moment, couple of millimeter over the bed.
Print the Great Gratouille and you'll be free !
How does it functions? When you scratch the nozzle, the crossed lines retains the filament pieces. Naturally, don't let the Great Gratouille without moving because the temperature could melt the PLA (the next version of Great Gratouille will be made of NASA Shuttle ceramic). No, be a gentleman and gently scratch the nozzle.
Immediately after scratching, the thin filament can easily be removed from the Great Gratouille.
And the most awesome of the object is that, if you forget to remove filament, when cooled, it will be a part of the Great Gratouille and remove itself the future filament!
After that I suggest you to go drinking a glass of Champagne (or Auchentoshan if you prefer) to celebrate the deliverance.
Cherry on the cake, you can use the tube to put a pen. With two Great Gratouille and their pen you have the perfect tool for dancing on the table and become the new Charlot !

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

20

The Great Gratouille was made using Tinkercad. Many thanks to Autodesk for making this great tool free !
You can see it here : https://www.tinkercad.com/things/ksPfVcAM2wS

title: 20 Inch Box Fan HEPA Fan Brackets.

description.text:
--Note-- Had to re-up the recessed bracket as I discovered a flaw in it I missed. Since corrected and re-upped - bad version was only up for a few hours after posting.

V1.2 - I took out some of the oblong cutouts as they proved to be points of weakness. I also extended the inward reach of the side mount version a bit. Also provided non-cutout versions.

These are brackets to turn a standard 20 inch box fan into a HEPA filter using an off the shelf filter you can get at Homedespot / Lowes / Wallyworld etc..

Three variants - one where the screw holds are easily accessible, one for slightly recessed screws (My fan has this type on the bottom), and a third for fan guards with no screws where you can simply screw into the side of the box with self tapping screws or bolt in if feeling extra OCD assuming you can get the guard off to get inside.

If using existing screws, may need to find longer ones. Cheap fans use as short a screw as they need so the beefed up screw area may be too thick for the stock screws.

I use 4 of them, one on each side, two on the bottom, and leaving the top open for easy removal. They are not snug, there is enough for wiggle room depending on the filter, but when the fan is on it sucks the filter firmly against the back.

This obviously does increase the load on the fan, so likely shortens it's life span in the long run. It does not cause overheating etc.. as it is pretty much self cooling.

Note: There is a cutout specifically to fit a screwdriver through so you're not trying to screw something in at an angle.

I'm printing in PLA at the moment, but I suspect ABS/PETG/Nylon would work better for these and require less infill, be more robust, and probably allow for a thinner base around the screws. PLA seems a bit too brittle and breakable around the screw hole. I've broken several of the thinner ones, and even the thicker one split when trying to use a screw just a shade too large.. a little super glue fixed that, but didn't take much to bust it.

Update: PETG works WAY better for these. PLA is just to brittle to handle much mechanical stress for something so thin.

Printer:

Creality CR10 / Monoprice Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Infill:

Varies

Notes:

Infill you can play with. I use 100% as they don't use much to begin with and I like things like this solid. Early prototypes with no cutouts were good at 25%, but with the cutouts I had to strengthen the tapered bottom and increase the infill to 50. Darned if you do, darned if you don't. I could have removed the cutouts, but I like how they look.

Given where I plan to keep mine, I was concerned that my screen would get scratched or that the button would accidentally be pressed.

I couldn't find anything available either commercially or as a 3D design, so I worked up this simple cover.

There are 2 versions:

The original version has sharp edges. I later updated the design with fillets for a more curved appearance.

If you would like one with customized text (for example, your name and phone number), it's available at my Shapeways Shop.

print_settings.Notes:: This model is designed to be printed with the rear side down on the print bed.

description.text:
This is a stock cheek riser I designed for my savage MKII but it should work for any stock with a comb roughly 1" wide.

In my particular case I used a cheap mouse pad and rolled it up to provide the space between my rifle's stock and the cheek riser. Any sort of foam/fabric should do the trick, different amounts can be used depending on how much height you need to add.

This was designed to be tied on so no modifications are required to the rifle's factory stock.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I designed this model to be printed with a width of .5mm using 2 outside shells and 20% infill gives a strong part that is still a bit flexible to fit to your stock's comb.

This model is designed to be printed with the rear side down on the print bed.

I wanted a tie on cheek riser that wasn't fabric as most available models are.

I started by designing the cross section U shape with one hole in it and tried various material thicknesses and infill along with different reinforcements around the holes. This allowed me to quickly print a test cross section so I could try and break it by putting stress on the holes and seeing how well it held up in general to abuse. I also tested how easily it would conform to the different widths along the rifle's comb. Once I had a strong cross section I made it to the required length and added some of the angled cuts.

The goal is to remove the rope/ball from the base. With very little parts, it was really easy to make - less than 15 minutes. Go to the video for the solution if you cannot mentally figure it out from the picture.

Video Solution:
https://youtu.be/NmcurEs-BIA

https://www.instructables.com/id/Simple-Rope-Puzzle/

print_settings.Notes:: PLA works well for the connector spring, but I've noticed there is big difference in elasticity between different brands of PLA (example the red PLA in the picture is too springy so it comes loose easily). You might need to experiment with the openscad coupler_depth/connector_dia parameters to get the stiffness just right.

description.text:
A classic puzzle adapted for 3d printing. The design is scalable in the sense it has a smart resize function that scales both the piece and the connector ring appropriately.

Hint: to connect the pieces, put the snap ring into one piece, then do a round/wiggly motion with the second piece. The idea is to compress the ring from the side until it snaps in.

Biggest challenge with this design was to make it fully printable without supports. I went through a few iterations of the connector mechanism, in the end I settled on this internal compression ring that gives that is compliant/springy feel even after it wears out a bit. It has a 45 degree interface so it doesn't break when taken apart (secondary benefit it prints without support). Second challenge was with sharp edges from the 1st layer and top layer: initially the edges would break very easily and could also cut/scratch or cause high spots during rotation. Chamfering the edges made a huge difference there.

Some predefined models are included, but you can use the Thingiverse Customizer to generate your desired scale.

Notes:

PLA works well for the connector spring, but I've noticed there is big difference in elasticity between different brands of PLA (example the red PLA in the picture is too springy so it comes loose easily). You might need to experiment with the openscad coupler_depth/connector_dia parameters to get the stiffness just right.

I created a 3d printed housing for the reactor lens, LED rings and arduino pro mini that I used to control them. I attached the communication pins for the UART 2 USB board I have individually so that I could remove them easily once I was done programming. This allowed everything to fit nice and tight.The original instructions call for 1/8th inch laser cut acrylic from panoko but I went ahead and got the 1/4 inch instead with matte finish. for the final effect I left one untouched and painted/sanded the second to remove the paper matting and clean up the ink. Layering them together gives the Reactor a good surface finish with lots of depth. I used solidworks and provided both the stl and the sldprt files. It's all friction fit, so no screws or glue necessary. Slot in the back allows for easy maintenance, just push with your thumb to open it up.

This is a simple paper holder designed to hold single page recipes off of the counter while you are cooking. It uses two 1/4 x 1/4 magnets to hold it to the underside of the microwave (or other piece of metal). When it is not needed, it can be easily removed and stored or swiveled farther under the microwave.

If there is not enough/too much friction to hold the recipe in the "paper holder", you can use a heat gun (or another form of heat) to push the tab in or out to get a better fit on the recipe.

There are two versions of the "arm". One requires support while the other does not. The "paper holder" should also be printed with support.

author: cnorth

title: Fallout : Vault Boy Bobbleheads Shelf (Remix for Makerbot print bed)

description.text:
This is a Remix of nasooralj's "Fallout: Vault Boy Bobbleheads Shelf" that has been cut into pieces suitable to be printed on a Makerbot Replicator print bed. The original model was 12" wide, which is too large to print on a standard Makerbot Replicator. At the same time, 12" is too narrow to comfortably fit seven Fallout 4 bobbleheads on a single row.

Parts have been successfully print tested on a Replicator Dual and Replicator+.

No supports are required with the default orientation, but may be needed for some slight overhang if you change rotation.

For the rectangular parts, you only need to print either the solid OR the hollow part, you do not need both. If you choose to print the 6 solid pieces instead of the hollow parts, I would recommend using minfill or equivalent. If your software does not have a minfill option, then I did test with 10% infill, but 5% should be strong enough.

If you choose to use the hollow versions for those parts, you will need to print 2 base caps for the underside of the bottom back parts as well. (Caps will not be required for the top or middle pieces as these will be hidden by the adjoining parts).

Follow the layout images for placement.

A full print with rafts may require 1.8 kg of filament or more.

Once assembled (parts will need to be glued together and filler such as milliput will be needed to hide seams) total dimensions of this resized and split version of the shelf are 15" wide x 10.7" deep x 7.9" tall. (381mm X 272.4mm X 201.7mm).

title: Prusa i3 MK2/s Threaded Spool Holder

description.text:
Inspired by @pauloremigio's Simple Spool Holder, I wanted one with a threaded nut to lock the spool in place securely. Includes threaded and unthreaded washers as well as a threaded nut to lock the threaded washer on tight.

Do not tighten the washer/nuts against the spool, the spool should turn freely. Instead, use a threaded washer and nut on the one end and tighten them against each other to create a barrier on the left side of the spool. You can also put an unthreaded washer on the right side if you wish.

title: Rostock Max v2 Hall Sensor Z-probe

description.text: Z probe designed to integrate into the Rostock Max.

Correct the hole size if needed to 3mm so that a 3mm diameter rod can slide through.
Secure the PCB with a screw. Drill a hole of the appropiate size for the screw.
Mount the bottom and top guides to the Rostock and make sure the rod slide without any issues tighten the assembly.
Drill a hole in the side of the square block for a screw and assemble the rod into the guides with the square block in between.
Place a magnet on the end of the rod and adjust as needed.

The boat: Place the model on the backside (it has 15deg) and print in spiralvase mode with enough bottomlayers to build the backwall(0.5mm).
I used a 0.1mm resolution and 7 bottomlayers for the hull. It was a challenge for my slicers to get a proper toolpath. With Cura i had the least problems by the way.

The seat: Place the model on the side and print it in spiralvase mode too.

The shield: Turn it upside down and place it on the bed flat, then print it in normal mode, spiral would not work proper(because of islands)

All the other parts could be printed spiralwise too but since they are small it doesn't really matter.

For a dual cockpit you have to mirror the cockpit.stl

Build

Clean all parts, watertighten the boat, color your parts if you like and glue them together.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iFnLUQjlFxI

This anemometer is intended to be used with an android phone.
It is mounted on its base via a balls bearing.
It's a 11x7x3 mm bearing extracted from the heads coil of an old HDD disk. Consequently it's a high quality bearing with a very small friction.
At the base of the rotor are inserted two rare earth magnets (4mmx2mm)
These magnets when rotating induce a variation of the magnetic field which can be sensed by the magnetometer of your smartphone.

I have also developed an android App which is able to detect the rotation speed using Fast Fourrier Transform.
It also allows to calibrate the anemometer using your GPS in an almost automatic way. You just have to attach the device to an electric bike and to drive at various (constant) speeds. Then data are captured together with quality indicators. You can then fit a curve with excel to get an almost perfect calibration.

This anememeter is nice but needs quite a lot of wind to start rotation...
A new one will soon be posted with a classical 3 cups shape.

Stay tuned !
it there : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2527455

This idea is not mine, Vaavud company sells this kind of anemometers : https://vaavud.com/products/wind-meters/

The red filament is provided by ArianePlast : http://www.arianeplast.com/
A really good quality one !

title: No frill Prusa i3 MK2S sideways filament guide

description.text:
I liked the bender head a lot (see https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1821211 ), but I did not have enough clearance above my printer for the cheap temporary enclosure I had in mind (a plastic box). So.. I quickly threw some parameters in a new Fusion design and here is the guide without the funny head.

I will miss the funny head...

This one screws (M8 printed thread) into the holes of the z-axis of the printer. It fits both in the left one and the right one. They are different size, do not know why.

Simple - no frills - no fun, still it works.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

50

Notes:

I went all the way in Slic3r and went for variable layer thickness, (0.07mm where the threads are and on top of the ring).

The lower part doesn't need support, the ring can use it, as on the M8 screw it is a bit fragile. You could try without though.

I used it as an excuse to familiarize with parametric modelling in Fusion 360

Now I can with easy parameters change thickness and diameter of the ring and all the geometric parameters that depend on it change on the fly. Good to have in the tool bag.

A fridge handle compatible with my old Zanussi fridge.

title: Dowel Lamp with low poly shade!

description.text:
This is a modern lamp that uses a light socket from IKEA and some wooden 3/8" dowels! the lamp shade is modeled in fusion and then reduced in meshmixer to give it a low poly look! the shade is printed in vase mode (spiralized outer contours) and is 140mm in diameter and height to fit most build plates. This lamp is for LED bulbs only as conventional bulbs would be too hot! please ensure that your bulb does not get warm enough to melt the shade! the light socket in the video/pictures is the IKEA "hemma", but the nicer "sekond" braided cordset should also fit! Enjoy!

Check out the build / timelapse / assembly video: https://youtu.be/C3G_T56NpWw

author: WildRoseBuilds

description.text: Wanted to try a hollow spool, instead of solid.

This is an exceptionally simple calculator for determining the length of carbon tubes required for any size of U180-styled quadcopter. The default values are based on the measurements I took from my 3d printed ABS parts, and I sized the frame for a 220mm diagonal measurement. I found the 180mm frame was really tight, and meant that any cables that hung out a bit from the main stack would get clipped by the propellers. This version should give more room around the stack, and allow for slightly smoother airflow and less turbulence from propwash interaction. I can't give anything beyond speculation though, as I haven't flown my new U220 frame yet.

The value 10mm_corner_offset is the distance from the bottom of the plug to the center of the motor hole, and 6mm_corner_offset is the distance from the bottom of the hole in the corner to the center of the motor hole. Adjusting these to match your printed parts should give a more accurate fit. The diagonal_size variable should be self explanatory.

The Makerbot Customizer doesn't give console output, so you'll need to save the file and open with OpenSCAD to modify. Results are given with the echo command to the console.

title: Outside Pi Zero W,  IR-Cut camera
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
An outside weather proof IP camera based on the PI Zero W and cheap Infra red camera with led illumination.
//--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------//
22/8/17
Front case added with wall mounting bracket and swivel mount.
Print in ABS

Use the windows as templates to cut around some thin clear plastic sheet. Silicone into the front case from behind.

silicone around the camera lens and place into case making sure the lens is focused and pi zero cable is attached.

If printed in ABS the ball can be attached to the front case using acetone.
The shield can be attached again using acetone.

Pi Zero can be held in place with hot glue gun or some other method.

The front case has been designed to take a 4 pole M12 connector, these are available from a large number of suppliers and are usually IP65 rated and above. As the PI Zero W has wifi only +/- 5vdc power is required to pass through the plug and socket.

//--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------//
16/9/17
Rev 2 case and ball joint added. The ball joint allows another 11 deg tilt to be added to the swivel joint.
Rev 2 case has the side slot removed and simple hole for M12 cable gland.

//--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------//
For software I you the supper motioneyeos distribution created by Calin Crisan which proves to by easy to setup and very stable.

https://github.com/ccrisan/motioneyeos/wiki/Installation
https://www.facebook.com/pg/motioneyeos

//--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------//
https://youtu.be/bRjoqS-7oRU
https://youtu.be/bk5GIO7d5E4

The swivel joint is a remix of mistertech's Ball and Socket Locking swivel components.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1785190

UPDATE 9/27/17: I added Creality_CR10_Extended_Extruder_Arm_2 and it should be more accurate to the original

I find the extruder arm for the Creality Cr-10 to be too short and the spring too strong for my weak and scrony "muscles." So, being the nerd that I am, I use science and 3D printing to solve an issue. This extended arm should give you enough leverage to easily open the arm.

Print at 100% infil for maximum strength and decreased chances of snapping.

Note: This may wear out over time and may require reprinting and instalation more frequently. This is not made to be a permanet replacement for existing arm.

Please post makes!

It's on the large side, 25mm inside diameter, and short - made to fit my husband's thumb.
1mm wall thickness - so you may want to re-size in tinkercad rather than before printing.
pieces are grouped, essentially ungroup the main piece until you get the two cylinders and re-size them to what you need, center align and group them again and voila...

remixed_from.author: BlacklightShaman
remixed_from.title: KUKA KR150 industrial robot scale model

title: Kuka KR150 - Movable gripper base part

description.text:
NOTE: Assembly requires gluing

This is a remix of part DE of the WONDERFUL kuka KR150 industrial robot model, by blacklightshaman.
This part is design as one print and has 2 axis, one of which has very narrow clearances, making it very challenging to print with an FDM printer due to gaps being fused.

This is a 3 part version of the exact same part. it is divided into these part:

DEtop - which is the part when the gripper base is
DEmiddle- which is basically the stem of the DE part
DEhinge - the hinge that allows the gripper base to swivel sideways.

Assembly instructions:

After printing everything and removing supports, Take the hinge and place it the hole in DEmiddle (flat side - down). it should sit snugly inside and not move much. if you need to get a stronger grip, you might want to scale it up in 1 or 2 percents (not to much or it will become either to fat or two long or both)

this than goes inside of the DEtop (between that walls) note that the side with the big circular face correspond to the side with the bigger part on the DEtop. First to a measurement test, verifying everything is sitting together, then, put a tiny drop of any glue you might be using normally for prints, from each side of the hinge, make sure you dont get ANY glue near the clearance. quickly snap it into place. While glue is curing, constantly operate the hinge manually so any glue residues will not cure and make everything stuck...

thas it - good luck!

title: Recirculating Ball Slide for 1" Square Tube (Improved)

description.text:
This is an improved version of my earlier ball slide (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:943122). It also uses 6mm dia airsoft pellets as bearing balls, but it is lower-profile and runs a little more smoothly. Note that while it looks like the balls in the oval circuit will just scrub against the tube, one leg of the circuit is raised slightly while the rest of the circuit is recessed so that the balls can recirculate freely.

So how smooth and precise is this ball slide? Firstly, by adjusting the clamping screws, you can tighten it to take out all backlash. However, being made our of plastic, is is never going to be as stiff as a hardened steel slide. You can increase the stiffness some by increasing the preload, but as you do, the movement becomes less smooth, and you increase the wear. For the most part, this is really only recommended for light or intermittent duty applications. It would be great for use on FRC robots.

Printer:

UDIO

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Print 2 of the ball slide parts and one keeper piece. After printing, run some fine grit sandpaper in the ball slots to remove any blobs or lumps. Do not over-sand!

You'll need 84 airsoft pellets (21 for each ball circuit) and four 6-32 x 1/2" socket-head cap screws. And also your aluminum or steel 1" square tubing.

Before assembly, tap the edge holes with a 6-32 thread, and also any of the mounting holes you plan to use on each of the faces. Make sure to clean out and debris.

To assemble, place each of the ball slide halves on the beveled edge so that both slots are facing up. Fill each channel with balls (21 each). Carefully place the keeper piece on top of one of the halves. Hold the keeper and that half together as you flip it over and place it on top of the second half. Make sure you align the halves so that the counter-bored holes on one half line up with the threaded holes on the other half. Insert the four 6-32 screws in the counter-bored holes and gently tighten.

When ready to assembly onto your tube, hold your tube end-to-end with the keeper and slide the ball slide onto your tube. Tighten all four screws so that the gaps on either side are parallel and equal on both sides, until all play is removed from the slide.

UPDATE: I've added some breakaway spacers on one of the mating edges. Break these away on just one of the halves and leave the other set in place. When tightening the screws, tighten the side with the spacers completely. Then use the screws on the other side to adjust the preload. Clamping these spacers tight will dramatically increase the stiffness of the ball slide.

comments.text:
Let me put a bit of criticism. Looks like I do not understand something... IMHO the loop of slider's balls will never re-circulate. Because if both rows of the loop are contacting the metal surface at same time, they got force in controversial direction, that will prevent the balls from changing their positions in the loop. I'm in doubt that the balls even will roll staying on same place - because next ball in row will prevent the rotation when moved to the U turn of the loop. So technically there is no difference between having these rolls, or just having small pins printed. Low friction pair (plastic/aluminum?) will just create illusion that it works.
If it high loaded node of the machine, it should get a wear signs very soon.

title: Prusa MK2S LED High Mast Light

description.text:
This is my 2nd rendition of some LED lights for my MK2S. These I adapted to a bow top so not to interfere with the operation of the X gantry at max height. Added in a filament guide as well.

They work fine with the spool holder either factory or the one shown in the photos. Make pretty good light for a small foot print. I used these LED's (below) and I used an old 12v router power supply for the lights. For the switch I used a small RC hobby slide switch and printed a small box with each end being for the box receiver so I can disassemble as needed.

The smaller lower profile lights are here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2485486

I attached the light switch box to the top of the power supply with some double sided 3M adhesive- did not want it to be permanently mounted.

On the original I used the basic mount from the spool holder to make the holder for the lights. Awesome spool holder unless you opt for the shelf mounted as I did.

comments.author: bjeffway77

comments.text: I've made one. It works! It can run rather slowly, too. The pressure gauge on my regulator seems to be broken, so I'm not sure how low of a pressure it will run on. The strokes are pretty late, though (see below). I wet sanded the bore of the cylinder by hand (wish I had a suitable arbor to use a drill). I made two piston rings out of paper folded into thin strips, then I used super glue to bond them in place. I used marking fluid to find and sand down the high spots on the rings. To seal the piston rod, I cut a gasket out of ~2mm automotive gasket material. I cut the hole for the rod slightly undersize, then worked it back and forth to wear a rather exact hole. A hard flick will only send the flywheel around about twice... but sealing up the piston was a big improvement. I can't even feel air leaking around the rod when it's stopped.

remixed_from.title: Raspberry Pi 3 (B/B+), Pi 2 B, and Pi 1 B+ case with VESA mounts and more

title: Raspberry Pi DIN Rail Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A remix of 0110-M-P's excellent Raspberry Pi case to remove the VESA mounting tabs and replace with a DIN rail mount.

The enclosure mounts the Raspberry Pi on the rail vertically, sideways on, with SD card slot facing up and connectors facing down and to the front. It therefore takes much less space on the rail than other cases that mount the Pi flat against the rail.

The case clips on the rail in the usual way. Hang it over the top of the rail then rotate downwards and it will clip over the bottom. A front-accessible notch at the bottom allows releasing the spring clip in the usual way with a fingernail or screwdriver.

The case was based on the Pi 3 bottom and universal Pi 2/3 top, so it should suit Pi 3 or Pi 2. The pictures show it with a Pi 3. Like the original, the board is secured into the enclosure with M3 x 6mm machine screws, and the two halves of the enclosure are secured together with M3 x 16mm machine screws. The screws self-tap into the plastic. Other similar size screws would likely work fine.

The small gaps between the parts of the spring clip are all at least 0.4mm, so this should be printable on most machines. The example in the photos was printed on a Prusa i3 Mk2 using Boots Industries orange PLA.

Downloadable STEP files are included if you want to make modifications.

description.text:
Inspirandome en https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:459354, he diseñado mi propio carro Y impreso para la prusa i3, la principal diferencia es que solo necesita imprimirse en 2 partes en vez de 4. Mantiene las medias estándar del carro de la prusa i3: distancia entre agujeros de 209 mm para la sujeccion de la cama caliente, de 41 mm de separación de los agujeros para el belt hoder, pero me he permitido una disgresión al hacer los agujeros que sujetan los rodamiento en vez de estar a 20 mm están a 22.5mm para sujetar los portarodamientos que tengo para usar. La pieza ya está rotada (52°) para que quepa sin problemas en una cama caliente de 200x200, con brim de 5mm. La pieza está impresa en ABS con pico de 0.8 a 0.3 de altura de cama y 10% de infill, 1.2 mm de pared y de fondo y techo. Se deben imprimir dos partes, y con cyanocrilato se pegan entre ambas. El belt holder tambien ayuda a mantener las piezas unidas ya que se atornilla en la union de ambas piezas.

El belt holder que se ve en el armado es https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:619347 y los bujes impresos con bloque incluido son los https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1430232. Los créditos a ellos por un muy buen diseño.
