description.text:
I found several slim-wallet-with-money-clip designs here. I was surprised at how much I liked them, but the spring/clip (printed with PLA, even with 100% infill) would always break after only a week or two. Guess I carry too much cash! I whipped out FreeCAD and created a design that spread the stress in the clip over a much larger area, without increasing the size or weight. I also customized the box for the number of cards I generally carry.

This design will easily hold 12 bills (unfolded) and 4-7 cards (ymmv). I've included the FreeCAD source for those who want to make the box larger or smaller

Printer:

monoprice mini 3d

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

20

Notes:

If necessary, rotate it so the closed end is on the build plate so that it will build without supports. Does require that your printer will do some minimal bridging to get the top edge of the window correct.

On my MP Mini I actually used a layer height of 0.0875mm, wall thickness 1mm, infill density 20%, print speed 120mm/s (I'm not very patient). Sliced with Cura.

clean up

The top edge of the window might need a little scraping/sanding, depending on how well your printer bridges.

If you stress the clip by putting in the maximum number of cards and bills (you're rich!) then the clip will deform after a while and you won't be able to get away with too many fewer cards, as they will slide out. If you suddenly find you no longer need as many cards, just re-print.

Within limits, you should be able to use your slicer software to scale this model in the thickness dimension to accommodate fewer or more cards.

comments.text:
I printed this and absolutely love it! I always carry a slim wallet because I like to carry it in my front pocket. I had not even thought of printing one until I saw yours. I have printed 4 of them to make sure I have a spare. I had no issues printing this on an XYZ 1.0 with the E3D v6. I printed in PETG and also ABS. They both turned out great with no issues. The abs I gave an acetone fog for added strength.
Thanks again for sharing the great design!
comments.author: Masterblasterll

comments.text: Thanks! Let me know how the spring holds up in various materials. I have yet to print with anything other than PLA.
comments.author: Masterblasterll

comments.text: I have a mini as well. I'm surprised how well your print turned out while printing at that speed.  Have you done any upgrade/mods to your mini?  How long did the print take?
comments.author: rideout9

comments.text: Hi! I've had really good luck with the mini. The only "mods" I've done are a replacement selection wheel and a tool holder; nothing functional. I was using Hatchbox black filament which seems to work particularly well at fairly high temp. I didn't log that particular print (I'm bad about that) but I think I was using a nozzle temp of 210C and a bed temp of 55C -- most of the colored filaments I've used won't work with a nozzle temp that high. Also, I don't think I mentioned it, but I generally run the first layer or two at a much lower speed like 60mm/s.

print_settings.Notes:: Because this is going up at such a late date, you'll want to choose whatever settings will allow your print to complete quickly while supplying sufficient strength that 2mm arms won't snap on you. 15% infil worked fine for me but you may be able to get away with as little as 8%

description.text:
UPDATE: V2 has better offsets, better reinforcements and faster print time (less material). Print on back, with vertical prongs laying on print bed, with supports.

NASA has published a nice set of state-shaped pinhole cameras meant to be 3D printed https://eclipse2017.nasa.gov/3d-stl-files unfortunately the meshes aren't all well formed so I recommend you preprocess the meshes through MeshLab http://www.meshlab.net/

The other deficiency which I'm attempting to address here is lack of mounting brackets. I only have two hands, so need to be able to mount my pinhole camera on a tripod, so I threw together this bracket. Just slide whichever of the pinhole camera plates you've selected, into the arms of the bracket, screwing the tripod mount onto your camera tripod, or if you have a gopro mount laying around, I've included a version with GoPro style mounting arms. I realize this is a bit late, as you'll need to print and test this tonight (the night I publish these models) in order to make use of them tomorrow, August 21st the day of the solar eclipse.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Because this is going up at such a late date, you'll want to choose whatever settings will allow your print to complete quickly while supplying sufficient strength that 2mm arms won't snap on you. 15% infil worked fine for me but you may be able to get away with as little as 8%

Once you've printed the bracket of your choice, to match the tripod or mounting system you have most readily available, and printed one of the NASA pinhole camera state-shaped plates, just slide the plate into the top arms of the bracket. It should be clear from the design but two of the arms go behind, and one goes in front of your pinhole camera plate. The spacing is 2.75mm, so there will be some tension, hopefully sufficiently to hols the plate in position, as the plate itself is 3mm thick.

Obviously, you can just as easily slide a piece of cardboard into this bracket. If you go this route, know that your best bet is to punch a hole 5.5mm in diameter.

Remember, if you don't have suitable Eclipse Glasses, stick with the pinhole camera and view the resulting image only. Regular sunglasses are are insufficient!

Happy Eclipse Watching!

description.text:
This is a backrub thing.  You can print it out and then try to find someone to give you a backrub with it.  Or if you are feeling generous, you can print it out and use it to give someone else a backrub!  Either way, it is a fun thing to print and use.
About Me:  I'm on a mission to create all sorts of items that are embarrassing to buy in person, I currently sell all sorts of such items through my company PriveCo, but I think that making these types of items at home is even more private.  I'm creating a bunch of designs and I'm going to put them at my website MakerLove.com.  
If you are a skilled 3D designer, I hope you will join me in making interesting things.

This one is pretty straightforward.  I printed it using my Makerbot Replicator using the default settings and it went really well.  
I used external supports and a raft, and it went well.  You might be able to print it without the support, but did external support ever hurt anyone?  
When you are done with it, you rub it up and down your partner or good friend's spine.  Wiggle it around, rub it up and down, and have fun.
Don't accost people you don't know with the backrub thing, this device is not for creeps.

print_settings.Notes:: Skirt

description.text:
I have an above-ground pool that I test every day during the summer. I bought a Taylor basic test kit. When it came time to refill it, I found I could get 2 oz bottles of chlorine test reagent #1 and chlorine test reagent #2 for about the same outrageous price as the 0.75 oz bottles. The big bottles work fine and they're more economical, but you lose the awesomeness of having the neatly-organized plastic case.

I created this case for the test kit that holds the original test vessel, the original pH reagent (I seldom test pH, so the small-size bottle of phenyl red is just fine for me), but 2 oz bottles of the two chlorine test reagents. It's all scaled to print on my Monoprice Mini 3D (barely).

The chemicals are sun sensitive. I originally printed it in all black to keep the reagents in the dark. Unfortunately, I store it outside where it gets direct sun and the black PLA gets hot enough to warp. Reprinting the cover in yellow fixed that problem. The yellow PLA almost certainly filters enough UV to prevent degradation of the reagents.

Printer:

Monoprice Mini 3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The sidewalls of the cover are thin (to fit it on my Mini). If you print in black, it will warp in direct sun. Yellow should prevent warping and still block enough UV to protect the reagents.

On an MP Mini 3D, with a 120mm print bed, there is no room for a raft or skirt. I had to break into the custom settings of Cura, choose Skirt adhesion with a line count of zero to get it to slice.

I designed this in FreeCAD using the Part workbench and exported the parts to Cura for slicing. For the Mini 3D I used a layer height of 0.0875mm, wall/top/bottom thickness of 1mm, infill density of 20%. As I said above, to get it to fit on the Mini's build plate I had to choose Build Plate Adhesion Type of "Skirt" and Skirt Line Count of "0" in the custom settings.

title: Case for Fastchip IIe horizontal control panel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a case for the horizontal control panel for the Fastchip IIe accelerator. To assemble put the cable through the hole in the base of the case bottom and then attach it to the circuit board. The circuit board sits in the case bottom resting on the two shelfs and then the top goes on with the tabs down into the case. The tolerances on the one I printed were just right to get a good friction fit between the lid and case bottom and the shelf and top tabs held the circuit board in place nicely.

author: malfunct

title: iPhone/Apple Watch Charging Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Pictured is an iPhone 6 with an Otterbox Symmetry case. This stand will also work with an iPhone 6 Plus, provided you have a thin case (less than 3mm thick on the bottom). The “Adapter Piece” pictured has a trough cut out to accommodate my thick case, but there is also a version which is flat across the top. I have included the dimensions of the adapter piece so you can design your own to fit your particular case. This stand will work for both the plastic and steel watch chargers. If you use the steel charger, there is a shim piece you can print (since the steel charger is thinner).

The parts you need to print are Stand Base, Left Side, Right Side, Adapter Piece, Watch Charger Cap, and Clip (x2). The Stand Base has recesses for ½” self-adhesive feet (there is also a version without them). The feet I used are like this:

https://www.amazon.com/Self-Stick-Noise-Dampening-Bumpers-12-pieces/dp/B001WAK6DS/ref=sr_1_6?ie=UTF8&qid=1503257904&sr=8-6&keywords=1%2F2%22+rubber+feet

The Right Side and Left Sides I printed with an extra layer added to the bottom, which I sanded off afterwards. That seems to give you the best looking seam when you put them together and it helps reduce warping. If you use the “base layer” STL file, set your first layer thickness equal to the base layer thickness. You could also try using a raft to avoid the sanding. I've printed these in both PLA and ABS, for ABS I recommend the "high warp" configuration which has “load spreaders” protruding from the corners which need to be cut off post print.

You may have to adjust the dimensions of the two clips so that they pull the left and right sides together fully. The 8.5mm configuration worked well for me.
There is a PDF with assembly instructions included in the download files.

Please give this design a like and upload a pic of how it came out! Design feedback is welcome too :)

description.text:
I wound up remixing this from the original piece since I wound up with the carriage flopping up and down after a couple prints. So, I moved the holes for the wheels 1mm closer together and thickened the mounting holes for a tighter fit. I also integrated it with the piece for mounting the print head, so the print head doesn't stick forward so far, and removing much of the extra plastic in the process. This makes for a much less 'front heavy' carriage. So far it still has very little slop for me.. I printed with 'armadillo' nylon alternative filament and it seems very strong.
You will need the front piece of the clamp from here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2143520

Photo shows my remixed clamp for 4020 fan from here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2510862 it has more offset on the duct to make room for my clip on fan.

title: Tronxy X3S X3 Cable chain system and Hot end Shroud

description.text:
The X3S hot end is interchangeable with the X3 and X1 Hotends therefore all the shroud mods available online will fit the X3S. The shroud in this series however has a cable chain mount built right in. This shroud requires a 50x15mm blower style fan and one 30mm fan.

To install the shroud first mount your hotend to your back plate, then mount the shroud to the back plate, after you have the shroud in position mockup the blower in place with the blower shroud to get the proper height you need, once you have the proper height tighten down the shroud to the back plate. Now you can install your 30mm fan in the inside of the right side of the shroud.

I have two versions of the filament cooling shroud available. Both should yield similar results

comments.text: So the existing stock fan is mounted round on the right side with this mod? And the blower fan on the left attached to the blower shroud...What's the large hole at the front for?
comments.author: Bladewall

comments.text: It does not use the existing stock fan. It uses a 30mm fan. The hole is just a legacy feature from my other version for quick release mounting which enabled you to access the screws for the hotend. This one can be thought of the same I suppose.

I float tested these at room temperature and had no water infiltration...however, the first cycle my son used them with the sous vide they all had water infiltrate and many just sunk to the bottom. So I changed this to a work in progress, I plan on trying some different slicing settings, possibly post annealing (heating parts after printing to near plastic temp), and maybe just flat out change the design to an open (think half barrel).

These floats will reduce heat loss from the top surface of the water while sous vide (cooking food sealed in a vacuum bag, so no concern about food safety!).

Sliced in S3D in vase mode. PET covered heated glass bed at 90 C, extruder at 250 C. 2 degrees in either direction caused part to fail and loss of clarity.

author: jeffdriscoll

description.text:
This is a replica of the Butter Bot from the show Rick and Morty. It’s as screen-accurate in size and detail as I could make it, and it was machined from aluminum. All of the joints have been designed so the robot is a posable figure for display, or even stop motion animation. I used a variety of techniques to build the butter bot because I wanted to learn, but most of the parts (the arms, hands, head, and body) can be easily fabricated using a CNC router like the Carvey and bent on a vice or brake.

The treads were 3d printed from ninjaflex filament, and the wheels/shoulders/eye were turned on a lathe. If you don’t have access to a lathe, these parts could easily be printed, or created from stacked (and glued/brazed/welded) layers of CNC routed aluminum.

I don’t have a single assembly file for the project, but the files I’ve uploaded here should contain all the plans necessary as individual bits and pieces. The “rough model” file was basically my work document to figure out global sizing, so it’s not very accurate to my final build, but all the other CAD files I’m uploading exist for either CAM and CNC routing, for 3D printing, or as direct reference for hand-machining. I made this before Fusion 360 implemented sheet metal fabrication, so all of the sheet metal parts (1/16” Al) are described in a separate Illustrator document. I’ve also thrown in a few sketches I used while I was working on the lathe, but I have since replaced those with accurate models for the wheels and shoulders in their own files.

To anybody who wants to build one of these: Good luck and I hope you have fun! I loved this project and learned a LOT about many aspects of working with aluminum. It’s a surprisingly intensive build.

I’ve also detailed the build in this YouTube video: https://youtu.be/3PpORrycZG8
And I had some fun teaching myself stop motion animation while making this clip: https://youtu.be/MByi1te9L8U

--------- Parts I Used --------
Online Metals
.063" 5052-H32 ALUMINUM SHEET (Body, head)
0.5" x 2" Extruded 6061-T6 Aluminum Rectangle Bar (base)
Aluminum Sheet 6061 O Bare 0.125" (arms, hands, face)
1.5" OD X 0.25" 6061-T6 Bare Extruded Aluminum Tube (eye socket – turned down)
0.625" Dia. Extruded 6061-T6 Aluminum Round Rod (wheels, shoulders – turned down)

McMaster Carr
6655K13 – thrust bearings for neck/shoulder joints
90630A110 – nylocks for neck/shoulder joints
95446A470 – shoulder screws for wheel axles
92949A550 – screw that holds the entire head together
92949A145 – elbow/wrist fasteners
92949A149 – shoulder fasteners

other
Ninjaflex filament – treads
India ink – treads (could also just have black ninjaflex)
Fisheye door viewer / peephole – eye
Wire and LED (glued on top of the head for show)

I needed to mount my Nexus 6 smartphone (phablet) on a post in my yard so I could hear and see it when I'm in my pool. Mostly, I wanted to be able to run the Wasp Repellent app which surprised me by actually working.

I originally printed it in black PLA, but it would soften and warp in the direct sun. I re-printed in white and all has been fine.
I put a strip of loop-side Velcro tape to cover the screw holes and hold the phone softly and snugly in the holder. Happy phone!
